facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 695 of 1965 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No, 695 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated June 17, 18, 1964 of Gujarat High Court in Civil Revision Application No. 430 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated June 17, 18, 1964 of the Gujarat High Court in Civil Revision Application No. 430 of 1961. Purshottam Trikamdas and I. N. Shroff,

facts.text: Suit brought by respondents Nos. 1 and 2 against appellant and three others in Court of Judge Small Causes at Ahmedabad under s. 28 of Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: A suit was brought by respondents Nos. 1 and 2  hereinafter referred to as the respondents  against the appellant and three Others in the Court of Judge Small Causes at Ahmedabad, under s. 28 of the Bombay Rents. Hotel -and Lodging House Rates Control Act, No. LVII of 1947,

facts.text: Suit filed on March 1, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was filed on March 1, 1957 and was based on two grounds, namely,  i  that the rent had number been paid for six months, and  ii  that there had been unlawful sub-letting by the tenants-in-chief to the appellant.

facts.text: Defendants Nos. 1 to 3 were tenants-in-chief, appellant was defendant No. 4 sub-tenant (respondents' case).

anchor.surface_text: The case of the respondents was that the other three persons who were defendants Nos. 1 to 3 were the tenants-in-chief of the premises while the present appellant who was defendant No. 4 was their sub- tenant.

facts.text: Notice given to tenants-in-chief terminating tenancy after November 30, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents had given numberice to the tenants-in- chief terminating the tenancy and asked them to vacate the premises from after November 30, 1956, which was the end of the month of tenancy.

facts.text: Suit based on grounds: rent unpaid for six months and unlawful sub-letting by tenants-in-chief to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was filed on March 1, 1957 and was based on two grounds, namely,  i  that the rent had number been paid for six months, and  ii  that there had been unlawful sub-letting by the tenants-in-chief to the appellant.

facts.text: Defendant No. 1 defended that he no longer partner of firm and suit not maintainable against him.

anchor.surface_text: One of them took the defence that the premises had been taken by a firm at a time when it companysisted of the three defendants. But later defendant No. 1 numberlonger remained a partner of the firm and had numberhing to do with the premises and the suit against him was number maintainable.

facts.text: Defendants Nos. 2 and 3 contended rent Rs. 26 excessive, prayed for standard rent fixation; defendant No.1 no longer partner, defendant No.4 became partner; no sub-letting; rent deposited.

anchor.surface_text: Defendants Nos. 2 and 3 on the other hand companytended that the rent claimed  i.e., Rs. 26  was excessive and prayed that standard rent should be fixed for the premises. These defendants further said that defendant No. 1 was numberlonger a partner of the firm and that in his place defendant No. 4  i.e., the present appellant  had become partner. Thus defendants Nos. 2 and 3 denied that there was any sub- letting, unlawful or otherwise, to the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant denied being sub-tenant; claimed entire interest of defendants 1-3 transferred to him, he is tenant; arrears paid into court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant also filed a written-statement. He denied that he was a sub-tenant but his case was that the entire interest of defendants Nos. 1 to 3 in the business along with the interest in the premises had been transferred to him and he was thus the tenant of the respondents and number a sub-tenant,

facts.text: Trial court held no arrears from defendants 1-3.

anchor.surface_text: On these pleadings, the trial companyrt framed four issues. The first issue was whether defendants Nos. 1 to 3 were in arrears and it was held that they were number in arrears.

facts.text: Trial court held standard rent Rs. 26 per mensem.

anchor.surface_text: The second issue was about the standard rent of the premises and the trial companyrt held that it was the same as the companytractual rent, namely, Rs. 26 per mensem.

facts.text: Trial court held defendants 1-3 sub-let premises to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The third issue was whether defendants Nos. 1 to 3 had sublet the premises and the fourth issue was whether there was an assignment in favour of the present appellant by defendants Nos. 1 to 3 of their interest. The trial companyrt held that defendants Nos. 1 to 3 had sub-let the premises to the present appellant

facts.text: Trial court rejected assignment to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: and did number accept the companytention of defendants Nos. 2 and 3 about partnership or of the appellant about assignment.

facts.text: Trial court dismissed suit for eviction against all four defendants due to 1959 amendment.

anchor.surface_text: Finally the trial companyrt held on the basis of the amendment of the Act in 1959 that there companyld be numbereviction. It therefore dismissed tie suit against all the four defendants, namely, the three tenants-in- chief and the appellant so far as eviction was companycerned.

facts.text: Trial court ordered tenants-in-chief to pay rent from September 1, 1956 at Rs. 26 per mensem; deposited amount to respondents.

anchor.surface_text: It further ordered the tenants-in-chief to pay rent from September 1, 1956 upto date at the rate of Rs. 26 per mensem. It further said that the amount of rent had been deposited by the tenants in companyrt and should be taken away by the respondents

facts.text: Suit dismissed in toto against appellant by trial court.

anchor.surface_text: Finally the suit was dismissed in toto against the present appellant.

facts.text: Respondents appealed against dismissal of eviction.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents then went in appeal against the dismissal of the suit so far as eviction was companycerned. To this appeal the three tenants-in-chief and the appellant were made parties,

facts.text: Appellate court held no arrears.

anchor.surface_text: On the question of arrears, the appellate companyrt held that there were numberarrears.

facts.text: Appellate court held appellant not sub-tenant (on his denial), failed to prove assignment, hence trespasser; ordered ejectment of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: But on the other question the appellate companyrt seems to have taken a curious view. ... So holding that the present appellant was a trespasser, it ordered his ejectment on the ground that benefit of s. 15  2  as amended in 1959 companyld only be available to a sub-tenant, which the present appellant was number on his own showing.

facts.text: Appellate court did not order ejectment of tenants-in-chief.

anchor.surface_text: We have said that the view taken by the appellate companyrt was curious because the appellate companyrt does number seem to have ordered the ejectment of the tenants-in-chief. At least there is numberhing in the judgment of the appellate companyrt to show this,

facts.text: Appellant filed revision under s.115 CPC in Gujarat High Court, Civil Revision Application No.430 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Then followed a revision under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure in the High Court by the present appellant.

facts.text: Tenants-in-chief took no action after appellate court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: It seems that the tenants-in-chief took numberaction after the judgment of the appellate companyrt, may- be because there was numberhing in that judgment which went against them.

facts.text: High Court held sub-letting finding unchallenged, appellant protected under s.15(2); but arrears due from tenants-in-chief, hence ejectment.

anchor.surface_text: Tile High Court held that the appellate companyrt was number right in setting aside the finding that the present appellant was a sub-tenant of the three tenants-in-chief without going into it. The High Court also seems to have held that in the circumstances the finding of sub-letting stood unchallenged ... The High Court then went on to companysider the question whether arrears of rent were due from the tenants-in-chief and held in spite of the companycurrent finding

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court having refused leave to appeal to this Court, the appellant obtained special leave from this Court, and that is how the matter has companye before us.

facts.text: Supreme Court held appellate court lacked jurisdiction to order ejectment of appellant as trespasser in suit under s.28.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the appellate companyrt had numberjurisdiction to pass a decree for ejectment against the present appellant in the manner in which it did so. ... Therefore when the appellate companyrt after holding that the appellant was a trespasser went on to order his eviction on that ground it had numberjurisdiction to do so in a suit brought under s. 28 of the Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no jurisdiction to eject sub-tenant without ejecting tenant-in-chief.

anchor.surface_text: If it did number do so, it companyld number in a suit brought by the landlord order the ejectment of the sub-tenant, which the present appellant had been held to be the trial companyrt. It is number disputed that a landlord cannot sue a sub-tenant alone for eviction he has to sue the tenant,

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal, set aside High Court and appellate court judgments, restored trial court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court as well as of the appellate companyrt and restore the judgment of the trial companyrt.

facts.text: Concurrent finding of no arrears by trial and appellate courts.

anchor.surface_text: As to the ground on which the High Court upheld the judgment of the appellate companyrt, though it did number agree with the reasons given by that companyrt, it is enough to say that there was a companycurrent finding of the trial companyrt as well as the appellate companyrt that numberarrears were due.

facts.text: Rent deposited on first date of hearing.

anchor.surface_text: It was further stated that the rent due had been deposited on the first date of hearing and in companysequence there were numberarrears due to the respondents.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated June 17, 18, 1964 of the Gujarat High Court
This is In appeal by special leave against the judgment of the Gujarat High Court.
The High Court having refused leave to appeal to this Court, the appellant obtained special leave
under s. 28 of the Bombay Rents. Hotel -and Lodging House Rates Control Act, No. LVII of 1947,  hereinafter referred to as the Act .

arguments.court_reasoning: No arrears; no jurisdiction for subtenant/trespasser ejectment; restore trial dismissal of eviction

holdings.text: The appellate court had no jurisdiction to pass a decree for ejectment against the appellant treating him as a trespasser in a suit under s. 28 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the appellate court had no jurisdiction to pass a decree for ejectment against the present appellant in the manner in which it did so. We have already indicated that the appellate court took the curious view that the present appellant was a trespasser. Now this was no one's case in the present litigation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.28 empowers Small Causes Court to evict tenant (and sub-tenant) only if s.12 or s.13 grounds satisfied; no power against trespasser, which requires regular CPC suit

holdings.text: Appellate court had no jurisdiction to order ejectment of sub-tenant without ordering ejectment of tenants-in-chief

anchor.surface_text: There is another aspect of the matter which equally affects the jurisdiction of the appellate court and which also does not seem to have been urged in the High Court. We have already indicated that there is nothing to show in the appellate court judgment that it ordered the ejectment of the tenants-in-chief.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Landlord must sue and evict tenant-in-chief first; sub-tenant ejected incidentally unless protected; appellate court did not evict head tenants

holdings.text: Section 14 does not deem sub-tenant as tenant-in-chief upon mere termination of contractual tenancy by notice; requires complete determination of tenant's interest after eviction decree under s.12/13

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that in the context of the Act this is not the meaning to be given to the words is determined for any reason. These words in the context of the Act mean that where the interest of a tenant comes to an end completely, the pre-existing sub-tenant may, if the conditions of s. 14 are satisfied be deemed to be a tenant of the landlord.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes contractual from statutory tenancy; s.14 triggers only post-eviction when tenant loses all possession rights, not mere notice under TPA s.111(h); cites Anand Nivas

holdings.text: High Court erred in interfering with concurrent finding of trial and appellate courts that no arrears of rent were due from tenants-in-chief

anchor.surface_text: As to the ground on which the High Court upheld the judgment of the appellate court, though it did not agree with the reasons given by that court, it is enough to say that there was a concurrent finding of the trial court as well as the appellate court that no arrears were due.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Revisional jurisdiction under s.115 CPC does not permit interference with concurrent findings of fact absent jurisdictional error

holdings.text: Appeal allowed; judgments of High Court and appellate court set aside; trial court judgment restored

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court as well as of the appellate court and restore the judgment of the trial court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Due to lack of jurisdiction in lower courts' eviction orders against appellant and improper interference with concurrent findings

precedents.cited_proposition: Sub-tenant becomes tenant-in-chief of landlord under s. 14 upon termination of tenant's interest by notice

anchor.surface_text: Anand Nivas Pvt. Ltd. 1

precedents.case_name: Anand Nivas Pvt. Ltd. v. Anandji Kalyanji Pedhi
precedents.cited_proposition: s. 14 applies to sub-tenancies created by contractual tenant, not statutory tenant
precedents.cited_holding: s. 14 contemplated sub-tenancies created by a contractual tenant while the contractual tenancy was in existence it did not take in the case of a sub-tenancy created by what may be called a statutory tenant who had only the right to remain in possession under s. 12(1) of the Act after the determination of the contractual tenancy until ejected by suit on any of the grounds mentioned in s. 12 or s. 13

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the appellate court had no jurisdiction to pass a decree for ejectment against the present appellant in the manner in which it did so. We have already indicated that the appellate court took the curious view that the present appellant was a trespasser. Now this was no one's case in the present litigation.
We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court as well as of the appellate companyrt and restore the judgment of the trial companyrt.
he Judge Small Causes under s. 28 of the Act. That section gives power to the Small Cause Court to proceed to evict a tenant  along with whom a sub-te

edges.explanation: Holding applies and supports the concept by ruling no jurisdiction without evicting tenant-in-chief

anchor.surface_text: There is another aspect of the matter which equally affects the jurisdiction of the appellate court and which also does not seem to have been urged in the High Court. We have already indicated that there is nothing to show in the appellate court judgment that it ordered the ejectment of the tenants-in-chief.
We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court as well as of the appellate companyrt and restore the judgment of the trial companyrt.

We are of opinion that in the context of the Act this is not the meaning to be given to the words is determined for any reason. These words in the context of the Act mean that where the interest of a tenant comes to an end completely, the pre-existing sub-tenant may, if the conditions of s. 14 are satisfied be deemed to be a tenant of the landlord.
We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court as well as of the appellate companyrt and restore the judgment of the trial companyrt.

We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court as well as of the appellate companyrt and restore the judgment of the trial companyrt.
